title: Injera
summary: Injera (Amharic: እንጀራ, ənǧära, [ɨndʒəra]; Oromo: Biddeena; Tigrinya: Tai’ta) is a sour fermented flatbread with a slightly spongy texture, traditionally made of teff flour. In Ethiopia, Eritrea, and some parts of Sudan, [1][2] injera is the staple; also eaten in other countries in East Africa,[4] injera is central to the dining process, like bread or rice elsewhere.[5][6]
